name: Bulkhead
title: Bulkhead
description: Learn how to use the MicroProfile Bulkhead policy to prevent cascading failures.

steps.name: Intro
steps.title: What you'll learn
description: Explore how to prevent a single failure from bringing down the entire system. MicroProfile makes this easy to do with its Fault Tolerance feature's Bulkhead policy.

You'll start with a sample online banking scenario and see how it fails when no fault tolerance is implenented. You'll then enable the MicroProfile Fault Tolerance feature and use the Bulkhead policy to prevent the failing method from taking down the whole application. You will explore the two approaches to Bulkhead, semaphore isolation and thread pool isolation, and the parameters used for the annotation. Finally, you will add a fallback class which will be invoked if the BulkheadException is thrown.

sections.name: backgroundConcepts
sections.title: Background concepts
description: We will use the MicroProfile Bulkhead and Asynchronous policies.
Bulkhead
The term bulkhead comes from the structure used in ships to create partitions. In the event of a hull breach, these partitions can be sealed off to prevent the rest of the ship from getting damaged.
The bulkhead pattern in software systems work similarly by isolating failures to prevent the rest of the system from failing.

steps.title: Java Concurrency with Future and Executors
description: In the Example: Bank Scenario step, it allows only a single virtual financial advisor chat session available at a time. Implementing Java concurrency by using Executors and Future removes the single chat limitation and allows multiple virtual financial advisor chat sessions available at the same time.

steps.name: AddLibertyMPFaultTolerance
steps.title: Enabling MicroProfile Fault Tolerance
description: Microprofile fault tolerance is a way for microservices to handle the unavailability of a service by using different policies to guide the execution and result of some logic. The MicroProfile Fault Tolerance 1.0 feature provides an environment to support resilient microservices through patterns that include bulkheads. Enable the MicroProfile Fault Tolerance 1.0 feature in the server.xml of the Liberty server where the Virtual Financial Advisor microservice runs.
instruction: Add the following element declaration inside the featureManager element to the server.xml file, or click <feature>mpFaultTolerance-1.0</feature>. Then, click Save on the editor menu pane.

steps.name: BulkheadAnnotation
steps.title: Adding the @Bulkhead annotation
description: Now that you've seen how our application can easily fail when overloaded, we will fix that by using the Bulkhead pattern. Add the @Bulkhead annotation to the requestAVirtualFinancialAdvisor microservice to limit the maximum concurrent requests.
When @Bulkhead is used by itself, the semaphore approach to bulkhead will be used. When reaching the maximum concurrent request count, extra requests will fail with BulkheadException.

You may specify the maximum number of concurrent requests using the value parameter, or by just passing the number into the annotation. If a value is not specified, the annotation defaults to 10 requests.
instruction: Add the @Bulkhead annotation with a value of 2 on line 7, before the requestAVirtualFinancialAdvisor method, or click @Bulkhead(2). Then, click Run on the editor menu pane.
Click Chat with a financial advisor to open a chat session with an available advisor.
Click Chat with a financial advisor the 2nd time to open another chat session with another available advisor.
Click Chat with a financial advisor the 3rd time to open another chat session with another available advisor.

steps.name: AsyncBulkheadAnnotation
steps.title: Adding the @Asynchronous annotation with Bulkhead
description: When @Bulkhead is used with @Asynchronous, the thread pool isolation approach will be used. The thread pool approach allows to configure the maximum concurrent requests together with the waiting queue size. When a request cannot be added to the waiting queue, BulkheadException will be thrown.

Multiple virtual financial advisors can service the requests at the same time. If there are no financial advisor available, requests are allow in the waiting queue. When the maximum number of requests on the waiting queue are reach, an error message will be display.
You can modify these two parameters:
<ul>
• value: the maximum number of concurrent requests
• waitingTaskQueue: the waiting task queue. This setting only takes effect on asynchronous invocation, achieved by using @Asynchronous

Change the @Bulkhead() annotation on line 9 to the following code, or click
@Asynchronous @Bulkhead(value = 2, waitingTaskQueue = 1).
The method annotated with @Asynchronous must return a Future. Change the method return type on line 12 to the following code, or click
public Future requestAVirtualFinancialAdvisor() {.
Change the return type on line 14 to the following code, or click

Then, click Run on the editor menu pane.
Click Chat with a financial advisor to open a chat session with an available advisor.
Click Chat with a financial advisor the second time to open a chat session with another available advisor.
Since the maximum number of requests has reach. The next request will be place in the waiting queue. Click Chat with a financial advisor the third time to be place in the waiting queue.
There is a limit to the number of requests that can be add to the waiting queue to prevent the system overloads. Click Chat with a financial advisor the fourth time to see the error message.

steps.name: Fallback
steps.title: Adding the @Fallback annotation
description: Use @Fallback(FallbackHandler.class) annotation to identify a fallback class that run when the requests are failed.
When the maximum number of requests on the waiting queue are reach, the fallback class can be execute to display a friendly message for the user to try the request again later.
instruction:
In BankService.java add the @Fallback(BulkheadFallbackHandler.class) annotation on line 9 to the following code, or click
@Fallback(BulkheadFallbackHandler.class).
Then, click Run on the editor menu pane.
Click Chat with a financial advisor to see the message to retry again later.
